description: From Dutch etsen (“to etch”), from German ätzen (“to etch”), from Old High German azzon (“to cause to bite or feed”), from Proto-Germanic *atjaną, causative of *etaną (“to eat”) (whence also English eat).

verbs.description: etch (third-person singular simple present etches, present participle etching, simple past and past participle etched)

entries.meaning: To cut into a surface with an acid or other corrosive substance in order to make a pattern. Best known as a technique for creating printing plates, but also used for decoration on metal, and, in modern industry, to make circuit boards.

examples: The memory of 9/11 is etched into my mind.
There are many such empty terms to be found in some learned writers, to which they had recourse to etch out their system.
